report_generation.note: Keyword-based check for DR/AMD/RVO mentions vs ground truth

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Clear screening-vs-diagnosis framing; good natural-frequency explanation; organized into all required sections; generally warm and simple language.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Misses the AMD ground-truth finding (unlike Report B); includes questionable/unsupported advice (e.g., yearly dilated exam based on age 50+, “normal vision on today’s screening” with only OD value, and some awkward/incorrect interpretations of CGM percentages).

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Includes all required sections; clearly frames as a screening (not diagnosis); uses natural-frequency phrasing; generally warm and understandable.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Some clinically questionable statements (e.g., implying retina vessels look normal from screening; linking lows to eye stress); misstates time-below-range as ~1/10 (it is ~2/10) and oversimplifies 4.6% as '0 out of 10'; suggests insulin adjustment despite participant labeled healthy/no meds provided.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Clear natural-frequency risk explanation, repeatedly clarifies screening vs diagnosis, includes all required sections, ties glucose patterns to eye risk, provides urgent follow-up guidance.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: A few statements are slightly off/unclear (e.g., time-in-range described as “days”/“4 out of 10 days” vs readings; “more advanced changes” may overstate model output), and some phrasing adds mild jargon/extra details (BP/creatinine comments) without clear patient framing.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Clear screening-vs-diagnosis framing; good natural-frequency explanation; appropriate routine follow-up guidance; includes all required sections and is generally patient-friendly.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Misstates A1c relationship (CGM GMI 6.7 is lower than lab HbA1c 7.3, not higher); minor numerical phrasing error ('1 out of 20 above 180' contradicts 12.4%); introduces extra symptoms (eye pressure, double vision) that are not clearly tied to DR screening context.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Warm tone, clear routine-urgency guidance, good linkage to glucose control and other risk factors, includes all required sections.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Major error converting 5.8% probability to natural frequency (“2 out of 10” instead of ~1 out of 20 / ~0–1 out of 10); adds speculative claims (screening affected by temporary glucose spikes/dips; mentions ‘low sugars often’ despite 0% <70) which aren’t supported by the data.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Warm tone, clear that this is a screening with routine urgency; good linkage to BP/triglycerides; includes all required sections and reasonable next steps.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Misstates CGM time-in-range (says ~2/3 in range and uses '95 out of 100 days' instead of readings/days); natural frequency for 1.2% is rounded to 1/10 (too high vs ~1/100), which may mislead.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Warm, clear, patient-friendly; includes all required sections; appropriately emphasizes screening vs diagnosis and routine urgency; accurately links stable CGM/A1c to eye health.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Natural-frequency framing is a bit too rounded down for a 1.4% risk ("0 out of 10" may understate); a few recommendations could be slightly more specific (timing, follow-up intervals) and avoid mildly speculative phrasing about long-term vessel stress.
